results.title: Rick -File X258375
results.creator_credit: National Institute of Mental Health (U.S.) and University of California, Los Angeles
results.brief_description: Demonstrates how the probation service responds to a youthful narcotics offender who - unbeknownst to the people coming into contact with him - is a probation employee himself. This film shows Rick assuming the role of ‘offender” and going through the same interview process as actual offender would go through.

results.title: Riches of the Veldt: South Africa
results.creator_credit: Bill Colleran, Louis De Rochemont and United World Films
results.brief_description: This film opens with a glimpse of the natives in their villages. These villages furnish native labour for the farms, cities and mines of the country. We are shown glimpses of Johannesburg, which lies on a plateau and developed out of the extensive gold-mining operations in that region. A visit to a mining engineer and his family living in the suburbs indicates that their traditions derive from the Dutch and English who constituted the original white population. There are views of the large cattle ranches on the veldt, the orange groves, and, in the south, grape country. The processes of gold mining and the demand mines at Kimberly are shown. The film closes with views of Captetown, the seaport.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bill Colleran, Louis De Rochemont and United World Films

results.title: Richard III (Perspective)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Shakespeare in Perspective Series”.
Designed to give a greater understanding and appreciation of the play by placing it in its historical and social context and by stressing its relevance to a modern day audience. Perspective offered by Rosemary Ann Sisson, author and playwright.

results.title: Richard II
results.creator_credit: David Giles, Cedric Messina, BBC and Time-Life Films
results.brief_description: A BBC production of Shakespeare’s “King Richard the Second” featuring Derek Jacobi as Richard the Second, Sir John Gielgud as Richard of Gaut and Wendy Hiller as the Duchess of York. One of thirty-seven plays by Shakespeare to be presented by the BBC over a six year period.

results.title: Rice in Todays World
results.brief_description: This film focuses on the importance of rice as a major rice crop of the world, focusing on rice-producing areas such as the Orient. Factors contributing to rice growing, such as proper climate, water supply terrain are addressed and this work also contains an overview of the processes in the culture of rice.

results.title: Rice Farming [COLOUR]
results.creator_credit: Jean Halliday, Lex Halliday and Australian Instructional Films
results.brief_description: Classroom film on the Australian rice industry: rice growing in Murrumbidgee irrigation area; preparation of the fields; mechanised sowing in the spring; subsequent flooding of paddy fields until harvesting seven months later; harvesting the crop yielding fifty bags to the acre; complementary crops grown on rice farms during winter; milling processes including sifting, removing full, polishing and bagging at local mills. Half the annual rice crop satisfies the home market; the remainder is exported principally in unpolished form.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jean Halliday, Lex Halliday and Australian Instructional Films

results.title: Rhythmic composition in yellow green minor
results.creator_credit: David Muir, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Australian eye I”.
A study of the painting “Rhythmic Composition in Yellow Green Minor” (1919) by Roy de Maistre (1894-1968). Also discusses the artist’s theories linking music to painting and his belief in harmony in life and art. One of the first abstract paintings produced in Australia - far advanced for its time. De Maistre also developed and patented a colour wheel.

results.title: Rhythm of a city
results.brief_description:
The first of the pioneer wildlife documentarist’s films to gain wide recognition, this film poem is built on incident and observation evoking without commentary, the rhythm of life in a city (Stockholm) ‘where the fittest survive’.
Won an American Academy Award in 1949.
